are all survivor and in this together

i hope this answer everyone question about this serious disease i have late stage fibrosis due to this complication i know nothing about until i have my biospy nonalcoholic steatohepatitison this page diagnosis symptom cause treatment hope through research point to remember for more information nonalcoholic steatohepatitis or nash is a common often silent liver disease it resemble alcoholic liver disease but occur in people who drink little or no alcohol the major feature in nash is fat in the liver along with inflammation and damage most people with nash feel well and are not aware that they have a liver problem nevertheless nash can be severe and can lead to cirrhosis in which the liver is permanently damage and scarred and no long able to work properly nash affect 2 to 5 percent of american an additional 10 to 20 percent of american have fat in their liver but no inflammation or liver damage a condition call fatty liver although have fat in the liver is not normal by itself it probably cause little harm or permanent damage if fat is suspect base on blood test result or scan of the liver this problem is call nonalcoholic fatty liver disease nafld if a liver biopsy is perform in this case it will show that some people have nash while other have simple fatty liver both nash and nafld are become more common possibly because of the great number of american with obesity in the past 10 year the rate of obesity have double in adult and triple in child obesity also contribute to diabete and high blood cholesterol which can far complicate the health of someone with nash diabetes and high blood cholesterol are also become more common among american biliary system top diagnosisnash is usually first suspect in a person who is find to have elevation in liver test that are include in routine blood test panel such a alanine aminotransferase alt or aspartate aminotransferase ast when further evaluation show no apparent reason for liver disease such a medication viral hepatitis or excessive use of alcohol and when x ray or image study of the liver show fat nash is suspect the only mean of prove a diagnosis of nash and separate it from simple fatty liver is a liver biopsy for a liver biopsy a needle is insert through the skin to remove a small piece of the liver nash is diagnose when examination of the tissue with a microscope show fat along with inflammation and damage to liver cell if the tissue show fat without inflammation and damage simple fatty liver or nafld is diagnose an important piece of information learn from the biopsy is whether scar tissue have develop in the liver currently no blood test or scan can reliably provide this information liver biopsy top symptomsnash is usually a silent disease with few or no symptom patient generally feel well in the early stage and only begin to have symptomssuch a fatigue weight loss and weaknessonce the disease is more advanced or cirrhosis develop the progression of nash can take year even decade the process can stop and in some case reverse on it own without specific therapy or nash can slowly worsen cause scarring or fibrosis to appear and accumulate in the liver a fibrosis worsens cirrhosis develop the liver become seriously scarred hardened and unable to function normally not every person with nash develop cirrhosis but once serious scarring or cirrhosis is present few treatment can halt the progression a person with cirrhosis experience fluid retention muscle waste bleed from the intestine and liver failure liver transplantation is the only treatment for advanced cirrhosis with liver failure and transplantation is increasingly perform in people with nash nash rank a one of the major cause of cirrhosis in america behind hepatitis c and alcoholic liver disease stage of liver damage top causesalthough nash have become more common it underlying cause is still not clear it most often occur in person who are middle aged and overweight or obese many patient with nash have elevate blood lipid such a cholesterol and triglyceride and many have diabete or pre diabete but not every obese person or every patient with diabetes have nash furthermore some patient with nash are not obese do not have diabete and have normal blood cholesterol and lipid nash can occur without any apparent risk factor and can even occur in child thus nash is not simply obesity that affect the liver while the underlying reason for the liver injury that cause nash is not know several factor are possible candidate insulin resistance release of toxic inflammatory protein by fat cell cytokine oxidative stress deterioration of cell inside liver cell top treatmentcurrently no specific therapy for nash exist the most important recommendation give to person with this disease are to reduce their weight if obese or overweight follow a balanced and healthy diet increase physical activity avoid alcohol avoid unnecessary medication these are standard recommendation but they can make a difference they are also helpful for other condition such a heart disease diabete and high cholesterol a major attempt should be make to lower body weight into the healthy range weight loss can improve liver test in patient with nash and may reverse the disease to some extent research at present is focus on how much weight loss improve the liver in patient with nash and whether this improvement last over a period of time people with nash often have other medical condition such a diabetes high blood pressure or elevate cholesterol these condition should be treat with medication and adequately control have nash or elevated liver enzyme should not lead people to avoid treat these other condition experimental approach under evaluation in patient with nash include antioxidant such a vitamin e selenium and betaine these medication act by reduce the oxidative stress that appear to increase inside the liver in patient with nash whether these substance actually help treat the disease is not know but the result of clinical trial should become available in the next few year another experimental approach to treat nash is the use of new antidiabetic medicationseven in person without diabete most patient with nash have insulin resistance mean that the insulin normally present in the bloodstream is le effective for they in control blood glucose and fatty acid in the blood than it is for people who do not have nash the new antidiabetic medication make the body more sensitive to insulin and may help reduce liver injury in patient with nash study of these medicationsinclude metformin rosiglitazone and pioglitazoneare being sponsor by the national institute of health and should answer the question of whether these medication are beneficial in nash top hope through researchwhat is most need in the management of nash is more research to well understand the liver injury find in this disease when the pathway that lead to the injury are fully know safe and effective mean can be develop to reverse these pathway and help patient with nash recent breakthrough in map the human genome and uncover the individual step by which insulin and other hormone regulate blood glucose and fat could provide the necessary clue the national institute of diabetes and digestive and kidney disease fund the nash clinical research network which comprise eight clinical center locate throughout the united state and a coordinate center at john hopkins university the nash network research the nature and underlying cause of nash and conduct clinical study on prevention and treatment more information on the nash clinical research network and the location of the clinical center are available at www jhucct com nash top point to remember nonalcoholic steatohepatitis nash is fat in the liver with inflammation and damage nash occur in people who drink little or no alcohol and affect 2 to 5 percent of american especially people who are middle aged and overweight or obese nash can occur in child people who have nash may feel well and may not know that they have a liver disease nash can lead to cirrhosis a condition in which the liver is permanently damage and can not work properly fatigue can occur at any stage of nash weight loss and weakness may begin once the disease is advanced or cirrhosis is present nash may be suspect if blood test show high level of liver enzyme or if scan show fatty liver nash is diagnose by examine a small piece of the liver take through a needle a procedure call biopsy people who have nash should reduce their weight eat a balanced diet engage in physical activity and avoid alcohol and unnecessary medication no specific therapy for nash exist experimental therapy being study include antioxidant and antidiabete medication top for more informationamerican liver foundation alf 75 maiden lanesuite 603new york ny 10038phone 1800goliver 4654837 18884hepusa 4437872 or 2126681000fax 2124838179email info access to medical journal article medical dictionary directory drug and supplement list interactive patient tutorial publication and the late health news visit www medlineplus org top the national cirrhosis result from the necrosis of the liver cell it is characterize by fibrosis formation of scar tissue and regenerative nodule the disease of cirrhosis and it stage lead to some or complete loss of liver function it may occur at any age of life cause of cirrhosis cirrhosis is most commonly cause by extensive and excessive drinking of alcohol there are other cause which include postnecrotic cirrhosis hepatitis b hepatitis c non alcoholic fatty liver disease autoimmune disease primary sclerose cholingitis stage of the liver disease cirrhosis autommune hepatitis metabolic disorder hemochromatosis wilson disease alpha antitrypsin defeciency galactosemia biliary primary biliary cirrhosis secondary biliary cirrhosis cystic fibrosis genetic hemochromatosis wilson disease chronic venous outflow obstruction budd chiari syndrome pathology of cirrhosis liver cirrhosis is characterize by the formation of regenerative nodule with loss of normal structure there are three type of cirrhosis a micronodular cirrhosis in this type the whole of the liver is uniformly involved regenerative nodule are on the small side being le than 3 mm in size this is due to excessive alcohol consumption b macronodular cirrhosis in this type some section of the liver are normal the size of the nodule will be variable and this type of cirrhosis is see in chronic viral hepatitis c mixed cirrhosis in some case a mixture of both small and large nodule are visible on and through the liver there are 4 stage of liver cirrhosis knowledge about the stage of liver cirrhosis is important for well prevention early diagnosis and effective preventative treatment stage 1 is the early stage which is characterize by minimal damage and a good prognosis for recovery and prevention whereas in the final stage 4 the liver is virtually completely damage and a liver transplant is the only treatment of choice read on to find out more about the different stage of cirrhosis stage 1 the first stage is know a the compensate stage this stage is characterize by inflammation of the liver tissue inflammation is confine to the portal area and do not involve other area of the liver this inflammatory process lead to minor connective tissue formation and scarring of the liver but a the name say these change can be compensate for by the body mean the body will adapt to offset the disease effect this stage is usually asymptomatic but on close examination some patient may have mild jaundice fatigue loss of appetite weight loss dry mouth nausea swelling of the abdomen abdominal pain stage 2 the second stage of cirrhosis is also characterize by inflammation of the liver tissue but at this stage the liver start to show area of fibrosis fibrosis are the stiff band that are form by the replacement of normal liver tissue with the scar tissue it is irreversible and can never return back to normal liver tissue however new liver cell can generate in this stage inflammation is not only limit to the portal area but involve the whole liver the change in this stage can be compensate for by the body stage 3 in the third stage the inflammation and fibrosis start to involve other area of the liver and the condition become more severe a the fibrosis extend to the other tissue it form bridge fibrosis bridging fibrosis not only impair the normal functioning of the liver but also affect the blood pressure level in the liver a condition know a portal hypertension a patient with stage 3 cirrhosis will not be able to digest fat so he may present with fat soluble vitamin deficiency vitamin a d e and k stage 4 stage 4 of liver cirrhosis is also know a the decompensate stage or end stage liver disease esld it is the most advanced stage and in this stage the body can no long compensate for the damage liver fibrosis extend to every part of the liver and a liver transplant is need to save the patient life stage 4 may also involve the spleen and kidney a patient with the 4th stage of liver cirrhosis may develop the follow symptom in addition to the symptom of the 1st stage fever pedal edema ascite jaundice pruriti plamar erythema easy bruise bleed stage 4 liver cirrhosis increase the risk of many complication e g ascite variceal hemorrhage spontaneous bacterial peritonitis hepatic encephalopathy and liver cancer some of these complication can be life threaten investigation of cirrhosis the follow test are perform to check which stage and what type of liver cirrhosis the patient may have liver function test albumin prothrombin time liver biochemistry serum alkaline phosphatase serum aminotransferase serum electrolyte sodium level serum creatinine viral marker serum autoantibody serum immunoglobulin iron index and ferritin copper ceruloplastin alpha antitrypsin in addition to these laboratory investigation imaging study check for the change in the size and shape of the liver some of these include ultrasound ct scan endoscopy and mri scan a liver biopsy is usually necessary to confirm the type and severity of liver disease management of cirrhosis of the liver in the compensated stage treatment of the underlying cause of cirrhosis can reverse the cirrhotic change in the liver if catch early enough and patient can lead a normal life patient should reduce their salt intake and should avoid aspirin nsaid and alcohol in the de compensate stage management of complication should be do ultrasound test should be do after every 6 month to detect the early development of hepatocellular carcinoma a liver transplant is usually need in the 4th stage prognosis of cirrhosis in general the survival rate of cirrhosis is 50 but this vary with the etiology stage and presence of complication much can be do through early intervention and look at lifestyle factor such a the food you eat and follow a strict liver friendly diet complimentary medicine no alcohol exercise supplement to boost your whole system and especially take care to look after yourself on every level when you have cirrhosis of the liver please use this a you wish i post this because i notice that there is some confusion in this forum regard the progressive stage and treatment available a well especially certain diet that are helpful in prevent the liver from progress to rapidly from one stage to the next which is the key to survive and avoid the decompensate stage 4 where only a transplant can treat such a damage liver for now one day this may change for the well but until then the good we can do is to stop it is progression and aid in regenerate new liver cell which if do efficiently enough can promote improvement in liver function all the good to you bless you all peace

just a brief synopsis my father in law wa diagnose with stage 4 lung cancer this past september he have been experience severe back leg pain for a few month and an mri discover a mass grow near his spine further test lead to the cancer diagnosis he start chemo in october the chemo wa do a good job of keep the cancer at bay but he wa feel horrible he sleep a lot lose all his hair and have trouble eat because nothing taste good to he after six round he wa start on a light chemo regimen his hair start grow back in and he have been able to lead a more productive life go fishing do yard work tinker in the garage and so on but the cancer is start to grow a bit especially in his adrenal gland my fil have another ct scan cancer have grow a little bit more the dr tell he that he can either continue do chemo try this pill i forget the name that is for lung and pancreatic cancer patient or sign up for a clinical trial my fil have been adamant about not participate in a clinical trial so he is go to try the pill even though some of the side effect are a little scary apparently people who take this pill can and should break out in a rash if they do not the pill is not work anyway it is really upsetting for i to know that my fil is run out of option i mean we ve know from the get go that this cancer would not be curable but it is still so difficult to wrap my brain around the fact that the year that they give he is almost up i keep pray that he will have lot of good day and when that is no long possible that he do not have to suffer through too many really bad day where my fil is concern i find myself really start to fear the unknown i worry about what his final day will be like i worry about how his death is go to impact my family especially my husband and our young child i try to take thing one day at a time but this weigh on my mind heavily

have other people hear of the connection between hcv and non hodgkin lymphoma it kind of scary but extremly interesting too anyone on here been diagnose with both here an article i find hepatitis c may boost non hodgkin risk finding may support screen patient for non hodgkin lymphoma webmd hepatitis c may make non hodgkin lymphoma more likely researcher report in the journal of the american medical association that may mean that people with hepatitis c should be screen for non hodgkin lymphoma note the researcher who include eric engels md mile per hour of the national cancer institute lymphoma are cancer of the lymph system hepatitis c is cause by the hepatitis c virus hcv hepatitis c infection can cause liver damage include cirrhosis and lead to liver cancer however most people with hepatitis c infection have no symptom and many have little liver damage although the risk of develop lymphoma is small our research suggest that screening of hcv infected individual could identify condition which may lead to cancer it might then be possible to prevent progression to lymphoma say engel in a national cancer institute news release engel colleague include thomas giordano m d mile per hour who work in houston at the baylor college of medicine and the houston center for quality of care and utilization study at the michael e debakey veteran affair medical center they study the 1997 2004 medical record of more than 718 000 you s military veteran include more than 146 000 hepatitis c patient the veteran most of whom were white man were 52 year old on average the study show that veteran with hepatitis c were 20 percent to 30 percent more likely to be diagnose with non hodgkin lymphoma than those without hepatitis c hepatitis c infection wa also link to a nearly threefold increase in a related cancer of white blood cell call waldenstrom macroglobulinemia the researcher are not sure how hepatitis c make non hodgkin lymphoma more likely or if the finding apply to other group of people hepatitis c infection is more common among military veteran than among the general public about 5 percent of veteran have hepatitis c compare with le than 2 percent of you s civilian accord to background information cite in the study the researcher call for further study to probe the possible link between hepatitis c infection and non hodgkin lymphoma

http www emaxhealth com 2 39 32952 how hepatitis c virus remain body html a study publish in the proceeding of the national academy of science pnas show that the virus block the action of a specific ion channel in the cell membrane that would usually trigger apoptosis the cell self destruct programme and in do so have evolve another way of protect itself from being eliminate from the body apoptosis occur naturally in the body to allow the removal of unhealthy cell or the replacement of worn out cell one of the way in which apoptosis can be trigger in a cell is to reduce it potassium level this can happen when the cell is expose to oxidative stress that activate a specific ion channel which act a a pore in the cell membrane cause it to open and allow out potassium ion however the research team have discover that a protein make by hcv know a ns5a is able to block the activation of this ion channel in liver cell enable these cell to resist cell death for long for a virus to persist in the body over a long time it have to find a way of manipulate the host cell so that it become resistant to apoptosis say lead researcher professor mark harris of the university faculty of biological science we know of many way that virus have evolve to do this but this is the first observation of a virus prevent cell death by manipulate an ion channel hcv affect some 170 million people globally and only around half of these will respond to treatment many sufferer will be asymptomatic some for twenty or even thirty year but the virus remain in the liver and it long tem damage can ultimately cause cirrhosis or cancer cell in the liver are often expose to high level of oxidative and other stress a they work to detoxify the blood of foreign compound such a drug and alcohol and to remove chemical produce by our own body say professor harris in addition the virus itself cause oxidative stress a it replicate in the cell the research show that the virus have evolve another way of protect itself from this natural process and to avoid elimination from the body for long the research team believe that continue research may offer a potential target for drug development perhaps through combination therapy we need to find out exactly how the block action work but it possible that two drug could be couple together one to prevent the virus from block the ion channel and another to induce stress to force apoptosis say professor harris it a very exciting discovery and ideally we d like to expand our investigation to see whether other virus that cause long term or chronic infection such a hiv have evolve the same ability source university of leed

we both were in early 60 and our kid laugh at we for eloping we need to marry early so i could be there for mark when his treatment start in january well through the year of 2007 we fight the cancer mark take 42 radiation treatment and do quite well we become the happy newly wed and live life to the full then in january 2008 after a routine colonoscopy mark wa diagnose with stage 4 colon cancer mest to the liver he go through surgery and start on chemo within 6 week it wa a very long road he wa on some type of chemo for almost 20 month he tolerate it well compare to some he wa very weak most day a lot of people here have lose love one of many year and even though mark and i only have 3 1 2 year together we have been join at the hip for those few year we live a very private isolated life in a very rural beautiful area we never have one unkind word to each other and just love being together i feel so lose now i look around i and i see thing we plan to do together this holiday season we have no idea that he would be go so fast but the one thing that give i comfort is we never leave anything unsaid between we i have just ramble in the posting but it something i need to do i share part hello my name is holly and i want to share my father story with you in january 2015 he wa diagnose with aml at the age of 49 this come a a total shock to the family a he wa healthy for all of his life after 5 intense round of chemotherapy remission and relapse and finally a bone marrow transplant i am happy to say he is now in remission he still have a long road of recovery ahead of he but he is well past day 100 of his transplant and is get strong each day i share this because i have see many story of struggle with this disease on this website but i want to remind you that recovery is possible the main goal is to stay positive that is very important for in order to win the battle a my father health is slowly improve our goal together is to visit people who are battle aml and to share his success story someone do the same thing for my family when he wa first diagnose and it make a world of difference in our approach to beat leukemia a a family member it is definitely difficult to watch someone go through this just remember cancer is not a death sentence rather it is just a change in lifestyle i hope this story will give strength for anyone who need it

i am a very healthy 42 year old have never smoke never drink and no drug i wa diagnose with colon cancer about 4 week ago that is a hard thing to take in i want the surgery a soon a possible so april 5 2011 wa my surgery date i have never have any surgery so wa pretty nervous but wa very relaxed the day of the surgery my tumor wa in the low section of my colon only 23 cm from the bottom so the surgeon dr blankenship in mobile al tell i that is wa go to be a tough area to get to but should be able to be do lycroscopic the surgery end up being about 4 hour the surgeon tell my wife that the tumor end up being large than expect about the size of a base ball i have 4 total incision one about 3 inch below the navel and 2 small on the right side of my abdomin and one on the left upon wake up from surgery i wa in extreme pain from pressure on my testical this wa the only pain i have and it wa strong the nurse say she could not give i any pain medication because my blood pressure wa still low from the anestitia once i have the medication the pain wa pretty much low i do have a catheter that wa remove the second day after surgery right after this i get up on my own and go to the rest room i have a hard time release to urinate i have to let it out in spurt for about the 1st two day after that no problem in that department second day i start build alot of gas move around but none wa get to the right exit point until the 2nd day once i do release it wa one of the good feeling in the world on saturday i wa release and go to the bass pro shop on sunday and buy i a new bass boat i hope this help anyone that is go through this and sorry for the spelling i try to get this post pretty fast thank and do not give up

web address http www sciencedaily com release 2010 01 100125172944 htm engineering a new way to study hepatitis c sciencedaily jan 27 2010 researcher at mit and rockefeller university have successfully grow hepatitis c virus in otherwise healthy liver cell in the laboratory an advance that could allow scientist to develop and test new treatment for the disease about 200 million people worldwide are infect with hepatitis c which can lead to liver failure or cancer and exist drug are not always effective to develop well treatment researcher need to test they in laboratory experiment in liver cell but it have been difficult to create a suitable tissue model because healthy liver cell tend to lose their liver function when remove from the body previously researcher have been able to induce cancerous liver cell to survive and reproduce outside the body but those cell are not sufficient for study hepatitis c because their response to infection are different from those of normal liver cell now bhatia in collaboration with charles rice of the rockefeller university have develop a way to maintain liver cell for four to six week by precisely arrange they on a specially pattern plate the cell can be infect with hepatitis c for two to three week give researcher the chance to study the cell response to different drug the new model describe in the proceeding of the national academy of science could allow researcher to test the effectiveness of various combination of drug include interferon a common current treatment and experimental antibody that may block the virus from enter cell the researcher use healthy liver cell that have been cryogenically preserve and grow they on special plate with micropattern that direct the cell where to grow the liver cell were strategically intersperse with other cell call fibroblast that support the growth of liver tissue if you just put cell on a surface in an unorganized way they lose their function very quickly say bhatia if you specify which cell sit next to each other you can extend the lifetime of the cell and help they maintain their function the current system may already be suitable to screen drug against the strain of hepatitis c use in this work however this strain which wa derive from a japanese patient with fulminant hepatitis is the only strain ever successfully grow in a laboratory environment the researcher hope to modify the system so they can grow additional strain such a those more common in north america which would allow for more thorough drug testing email or share this story more story source adapt from material provide by massachusetts institute of technology via eurekalert a service of aaa journal reference 1 alexander plo salman khetani et al persistent hepatitis c virus infection in microscale primary human hepatocyte culture proceeding of the national academy of science 2010 in press need to cite this story in your essay paper or report use one of the follow format happy father day to all i recently warn on this board in reply to another post about the potential danger of drink alcohol after the hcv treatment i wa warn folk to not be deceive by supposedly normal bloodwork if this is educational to anyone or can serve a a cautionary tale for anyone then it will have been worthwhile for anyone who may be interested here are my most recent number from approximately ten day ago albumin 4 1 bilirubin total 0 5 alp 55 ast 28 alt 23 wbc 5 0 rbc 4 1 hemoglobin 13 2 hemocrit 38 mcv 95 mch 32 6 platelet 234k ggt 34 point 12 4 inr 1 0 ultrasound of liver everything appear normal would not you agree that the above look pretty good my doctor comment to i wa that the majority of my patient would kill to have those number well the rest of the story is not that great here the kicker i also have the ash fibrosure test for those unfamiliar a normal liver score under 25 my score wa 70 bridge fibrosis w many septae cirrhosis officially is anything above 74 it is largely a matter of semantic since many doc regard bridge fibrosis a early cirrhosis way too close for comfort for moi anyway i am seriously consider take the heptech supplement protocol and am presently do my due diligence research will keep you post meanwhile i hope that all are enjoy the weekend pugdaddy

i think this article might be helpful to the forum can i be an organ donor even if i have hepatitis by charles daniel about com question can i be an organ donor even if i have hepatitis answer yes you can some people think that have hepatitis mean that they can not be an organ donor this is a myth people can still be an organ donor and have acute or even chronic hepatitis organ donation is a tremendous act of kindness and there is a great need for organ donor of all age in fact there is no age limit even if your liver is not in good enough shape for donation perhaps other organ and tissue could be use by someone else here are example of organ in addition to the liver that can be use heart intestine kidney lung and pancrea in addition certain tissue can also be use bone cornea sclerae tendon and certain vein there are however disease that will prevent organ donation example of two relatively common disease include being hiv positive and having actively spread cancer source donate life america retrieve august 18 2008 understanding donation united network for organ sharing retrieve august 18 2008 medium information

for all type of aml http www bizjournal com memphis news 2013 09 23 st jude find new way to i d bone html link to full article researcher at st jude childrens research hospital have discover a new way to identify bone marrow donor that could dramatically improve survival rate for transplant recipient the risk of death follow bone marrow transplantation can be reduce about 60 percent use a new technique to identify bone marrow donor who make the most potent cancer fight immune cell accord to research from st jude the research build on an early st jude discovery that specialized immune cell call natural killer nk cell dispatch cancer cell more efficiently when they carry a particular version of a kir protein on their surface kir is short for killer cell immunoglobulin like receptor kir protein regulate nk cell for this study researcher review the outcome of more than 300 bone marrow transplant perform at st jude over a 10 year period the transplant involve patient battle both acute lymphoblastic and acute myeloid leukemia a well a other condition investigator find that patient were far more likely to have survive the transplant and far le likely to had their disease progress if their new bone marrow come from donor whose nk cell include the same version of the protein rather than the alternative form this approach should dramatically improve the outcome for patient undergo bone marrow transplantation regardless of their age or underlying condition say wing leung m d ph d chair of the st jude department of bone marrow transplantation and cellular therapy nk cell also play an important role in autoimmune disorder chronic infection and other condition so these result will likely have an impact beyond cancer

lung cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth in tissue of the lung this growth may lead to metastasis which is the invasion of adjacent tissue and infiltration beyond the lung the vast majority of primary lung cancer are carcinoma of the lung derive from epithelial cell lung cancer the most common cause of cancer relate death in man and the second most common in woman after breast cancer 1 is responsible for 1 3 million death worldwide annually 2 the most common symptom are shortness of breath cough include cough up blood and weight loss 3 the main type of lung cancer are small cell ography ct scan the diagnosis is confirm with a biopsy this is usually perform via bronchoscopy or ct guide biopsy treatment and prognosis depend upon the histological type of cancer the stage degree of spread and the patient performance status possible treatment include surgery chemotherapy and radiotherapy with treatment the five year survival rate is 14 3 rene glenn 08 03 2008 in beloved memory

the question should i retire i may not be restaurant rich but i can make it the rest of my life without work i think but of course i will need to pay for health insurance for five year until medicare kick in i am factor in 250k for out of pocket medical expense which is nothing these day i am in very good physical shape for my age and work a blue collar job that pay relatively well for the area i live in but i am bored of it tired of the hustle and want to do more bucket list stuff a well a work my body and nutrition to a high standard the background i wa diagnose with cll stage zero and still hold in early 2012 at the age of 57 the only cancer i know of on either side of my family i have my spleen check out at that time via sonogram with no issue after three year with no symptom my oncologist quit his practice with little notice which wa a blessing in disguise a this doctor seem disengage which he wa of course a he know he wa check out i find a new hematologist oncologist who i much prefer this doc do not give i the apparently typical no big deal cll seem to elicit and instead give i the straight dope be prepare for possible treatment within three to five year twenty year without symptom is probably not in the card i wa give a baseline ct scan which show the lymph gland in my upper chest and neck enlarge but not alarmingly so my spleen and liver are still look ok too my number were up slightly a they seem to be every year but not much so far so good however shortly after the ct scan i have routine meniscus surgery due to a minor injury two day after surgery i develop some weird unrelated symptom blood in my urine and plantar fasciitus what the fuck after a week the bloody urine stop although it cause temporary anemia i wa check for bladder cancer which wa negative the plantar fasciitus wa excruciating but luckily after two week it disappear a mysteriously a it have appear i also have swollen lymph node under my chin a week after the other two vanish but they also vanish within a week the doc were mystify but i seem fine now my cbc number are actually well than before the surgery except i later take a vacation and come down with an upper respiratory problem bad cold the day i fly back home i can count on one hand the number of day i have been sick enough to feel i could not work make that two hand now but i am feel well and should be back to work monday this recent weirdness may mean nothing but it do give i pause i have see more doc this year than the previous 59 i have theory for all of it which is more than the doc do but it all have pas and i am back to square one anyway i realize my time is short than it once wa which is the bad feature of cll i could last twenty five year or twenty five month and there seem to be no way to get a good bead on it i am disappoint a several of my blood relative have make it to the century mark give or take a few year but i remain upbeat

vitamin e improve liver health june 21 2010 by carey rossi a multi center nih study have link long term vitamin e supplementation to improved liver health this seem to be the case particularly in those suffer from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis nash an obesity associate chronic liver disease that can lead to cirrhosis liver cancer and death nash resemble alcoholic liver disease but occur in people who drink little or no alcohol the major feature in nash is fat in the liver along with inflammation and damage even though it affect 2 5 of american most people with nash feel well and are not aware that they have a liver problem an additional 10 20 of american have fat in their liver but no inflammation or liver damage a condition call fatty liver or nonalcoholic fatty liver disease nafld both nash and nafld are become more common possibly because of the great number of american with obesity which make this recent study focus on vitamin e more intriguing publish in the new england journal of medicine the study find that supplement with 800 iu of vitamin e daily improve the liver of nash patient who currently have no approve treatment for the disease after 96 week of treatment just over two year vitamin e improve all feature of nash with the exception of the amount of scar tissue in the liver specifically 43 of those treat with vitamin e compare with only 19 of those who receive a placebo fatty liver disease is a grow problem in the you s and we currently have no approve medication to offer patient say brent tetri m d a hepatologist at saint louis university liver center and study researcher in a prepared statement with this study were pleased to find that vitamin e should help some of our patient share relate post vitamin e protect lung from pollution 0

http www onemedplace com blog archive 3124 melanoma drug call a breakthrough after study melanoma2scientists are call plexxikon experimental skin cancer drug a breakthrough after it successfully shrink tumor in clinical trial patient researcher at sloan kettering memorial cancer center in new york find that plx4032 cause tumor to shrink in 70 percent of patient with a particular genetic mutation two of the 27 patient who participate in the study see their tumor disappear completely the result are a vast improvement over chemotherapy which only shrink tumor in 13 to 15 percent of melanoma patient melanoma is the deadly form of skin cancer plx4032 work by block the activity of a cancer cause gene mutation that is involve in 50 to 60 percent of melanoma approximately 40 percent of patient without the gene mutation do not respond to plx4032 researcher at sloan kettering expect to start a large phase ii trial at the end of the year an international phase iii trial is plan for late 2009 or early 2010 the phase iii trial is expect to involve several hundred patient berkeley ca base plexxikoni is develop plx4032 in conjunction with roche plx4032 fare well than roche cancer drug avastin which fail a phase ii clinical trial avastin have previously show some promise against melanoma but a last minute review find that it ultimately do not confer a significant survival benefit however avastin perform well in another clinical trial involve patient with colon cancer the study find that avastin shrank liver tumor in 78 percent of colon cancer patient melanoma is highly treatable if catch early company such a electro optical science and melanoscan are develop early diagnostic system to catch melanoma while they are still in a treatable stage therapeutic for melanoma are being develop at biovex avax technology ganymed pharmaceutical peplin limit and amplimed corporation

hepatitis central november 28 2011 three reason to be wary of recently publicize milk thistle doubt because conflict information about milk thistle can be confusing to those want to protect their liver get the whole story about the late study by nicole cutler l ac the extract of milk thistle is widely accept a the most effective herbal remedy for liver ailment include chronic hepatitis c this popular herb is take by those who do not want or are ineligible for hepatitis c treatment have previously fail treatment or who want to increase their chance of a successful treatment base on a long history of being liver specific a potent antioxidant an anti inflammatory and an immune modulator it is no surprise that people with chronic hepatitis c often supplement with milk thistle extract however a recent presentation at the 2011 american association for the study of liver disease annual meeting cast doubt on this popular liver wellness practice the basis of hundred of medical study milk thistle extract have demonstrate a beneficial liver effect in the lab in animal study and human trial more often than it have show no benefit a publish in the march 2011 edition of the journal of research in medical science researcher find that patient with chronic hepatitis c take milk thistle 650 mg of silymarin a day for six month have improve level of hepatitis c rna improve liver enzyme level alt and ast reduce hepatic fibrosis and improve quality of life a publish in the february 2008 edition of hepatology a large trial of over 1 000 previous non responder with advanced chronic hepatitis c find that supplement with milk thistle result in significant improvement in fatigue nausea liver pain anorexia muscle and joint pain and general health read the article milk thistle bolster hcv treatment to learn of five more study of milk thistle and hepatitis c

i hope this will save some of you what i go and still go through i have t1c tumor 3 4 all confine per annum 4 ideal candidate for rp i choose to go with the da vinchi which may have seal my fate post surgery all the cancer site were leave behind and some 14cc of the gland i am due for radiation and homone therapy the most agressive tumor wa cut in half it is true that the surgeon can make the difference but i hear too many similar story already my experience is do not go for the da vinchi if you have agressive tumor 4 or 5 it is locate near the bladder neck or wall you are a narrow body type not enough room to manouver inside there is a new version of da vinchi that include an ultrasound probe to avoid these very issue it is in clinical trial currently i think it is in mayo clinic go to where there is a dedicated urology encology department just more people to consult with and get advice from hope yu make the right choice and do well

this article need to be look at by everybody this is awesome news grapefruit compound may help fight hepatitis c infection by david liu ph d feb 6 2008 3 23 35 prime ministerwednesday feb 6 2008 foodconsumer org a compound naturally occur in grapefruit and other citrus fruit may help get rid of hepatitis c virus accord to a study publish in an upcoming issue of the journal hematology the study lead by researcher at the massachusetts general hospital center for engineering in medicine show naringerin a flavonoid find in grapefruit block the secretion of hepatitis c virus from infected cell hepatitis c virus need to latch onto a very low density lipoprotein vldl a so call bad cholesterol to pas on the infection to other cell in the liver the effect wa observe in cultured cell line these result suggest that lipid lower drug a well a supplement such a naringenin may be combine with traditional antiviral therapy to reduce or even eliminate hcv from infected patient say yaakov nahmias phd of the mgh cem the paper lead author early study show hepatitis c virus need vldl to maintain it infection and naringenin can reduce secretion of vldl from liver cell the current study wa mean to examine whether the compound might also lower hcv secretion from infected cell the current antiviral medication can treat 50 percent of case but 70 percent are expect to develop chronic infection lead to cirrhosis or liver cancer in the end the researcher say naringerin or other lipid lower drug could be use with other antiviral medication to treat hepatitis c infection if the effect is confirm in human trial

i know most of we with anxiety also suffer hypochondria which is what start our anxiety anywhoo i come across this story i hope you all enjoy i descend into hypochondria at age 39 when i find a tiny lump in my breast normally i would not have worry my breast are naturally very dense and lumpy and my doctor have never seem concerned but this particular lump appear during the most difficult time of my lifein the midst of watch my father die of cancer right after i find it i go with my family to dad oncologist office where we would find out whether a hellish about of radiation and chemo have kill the cancer grow in dad esophagus while we wait i look at one of those plastic card that explain how to do a breast self exam i wa still hold the card when the doctor come in and clip some x ray to a light board he point to a small dark spot on my father liver the cancer wa spread when i could stop cry i realize i wa still clutch the breast exam card it seem like a sign i go home and google breast lump and what i read make my hand shake and my heart race suddenly i could not think of anything else in the shower at the dinner table drive the kid to school all i could think about wa die after that i really wa sickjust not with cancer hypochondria might seem like a joke a label you pin on a friend whose health drama never amount to anything but like depression or anxiety hypochondria is a recognize psychiatric disorder it affect an estimate 1 to 5 percent of american and like those disorder it exist on a continuum from people who simply worry excessively about their health to those who are completely debilitate by fear true hypochondriac do not just make up fake symptom and imaginary pain in a bid for attention instead every time a genuine symptom appear they believe that something is terribly wrong when a test turn up nothing a hypochondriac worry anyway sure the next test or doctor will uncover a serious or even fatal illness i do not imagine the lump in my breast what make i a hypochondriac is that no reassuring mammogram ultrasound or mri could ever convince i i wa not die after that first panicky google search i go straight to my ob gyns office to get the lump check out a a nurse gently prod and knead i chat with she try to calm myself down i wa probably overreact i say and explain that my fatherthe one person who could make i feel both completely protect and completely sure of my own strengthwas die a close a dad and i were it wa hard to separate what wa happen to he from what wa happen to i the nurse nod kindly then she say oop there s a mass a word like mass have a way of strip all logic from the conversation the nurse say it wa probably nothing but i need a mammogram and an ultrasound to be sure she tell i repeatedly that this mass do not feel like cancer to she that 80 percent of lump even the really suspicious one do not turn out to be cancer that it wa not time to start plan my funeral but to a woman with a mass in her breast and a die father the word funeral work like a dirty bomb explode into fragment that lodge deep in the brain the test only confirm that i have extremely dense breast tissuethe kind that make it nearly impossible for a radiologist to see anything in a mammogram or an ultrasound the next step a biopsy that turn out fine and the cheerful surgeon report that he wa not worried about i at all but then he say i need to return for another ultrasound in three month wa he hide something if there wa nothing amiss why do i need to come back a it turn out dense breast tissue is a risk factor for cancer which is why neither that surgeon nor one i consult for a second opinion would give i an all clear three time that first year i return for schedule exam on two other occasion i show up with new lump i wa worried about every time my test result show nothing wrong but instead of feel relieved i would brood about the cancer in hide the one the doctor do not catch i get so worried i could hardly work i cancel dinner party refuse to plan for the future when decoration go on sale after the holiday i d think i might not live to see next christmas and buy nothing meanwhile my parent come to stay with i and my family so i could help mom care for dad one of my son try to understand his grandfather illness say you are not go to get sick too are you mommy he look up at i trustingly and the fear rise up in my throat so thick i could hardly breathe before long the stress lead to more symptom that seem to warrant follow up insomnia heart palpitation irregular period a constant stomach ache over the next few year i have pelvic ultrasound a colonoscopy an endoscopy a colposcopy an ekg and countless blood testsand nothing wa wrong most of the test i suspect were order by my amazingly patient doctor to quell my fear but the more testing i have the more worried i become good test result were no solace during the three year it take my father to die and the grieve year afterward for people debilitate by hypochondria antidepressant and therapy may help but i never consider these option because like so many hypochondriac i do not realize i wa one what cure i is the fact that i do not die time pas after my father death and i begin to recognize the connection between my fear and my grief over his loss i realize that even if i could not banish that fear entirely i could take step to keep it from spiral out of control eventually i stop think of my body a a time bomb and begin finally to think of it a the very thing that let i live a happy life these day i sleep well and i laugh more checkup still make i nervous but i talk myself out of the tree by remember all the test and biopsy that turn out fine i no long google every little ache and pain because of the inevitable caveat rarely these are also symptom of a more serious condition instead i take a wait and see approach i m more likely to worry if i m exhausted or stress so i get eight hour of sleep and i never skip my workout i have a happy marriage healthy child deep friendship interesting work that s always been trueby themselves such blessing are no protection from hypochondria but i now understand that a constant fear of death is the sure way to ruin my own bless life and in it own way my about with hypochondria have turn out to be a gift the daily irritation that use to drive i to distractiontraffic delay flaky coworker cancel appointmentshardly touch i now i m too busy feel grateful to be alive

i have surgery for carcinoid lung cancer almost 3 year ago my right middle lobe wa remove since then they have been monitor my chromagranin a blood level every 90 day after a while of it stay around 3 max is 32 it start to rise it go from 3 3 to 8 to 11 to 13 still normal range but not a good trend my oncologist wa try to get i set up for an octrescan to see where it might be come back they are expensive and medicare do not want to pay for it pet scan are usually useless for find carcinoid i start do some research on the actual carcinoid test itself and find some thing the oncologist do not know turn out that if you are on prilosec it will screw up the result he do not know that and neither do the lab do the test i have been on prilosec for a long time for acid reflux my mom die of esophageal cancer from acid reflux i stop take the prilosec and wait a month for it to clear my system and get the oncologist to repeat the chromagranin a test again this time it wa 4 1 so that mean all the result while i wa on prilosec were useless so now we are basicly start over to get a baseline and so on i guess the moral of the story is do not trust the doc or the lab to know all the interaction and if you are get lab result that are disturb do some research on your own to make sure something else is not affect the result dave

early detection of lung cancer in a high risk population define by pft biomarker and ct scan summary lung cancer is the number one cancer killer in kentucky and have a very high incidence within the 5th congressional district of kentucky 110 8 case per 100 000 in period 1996 2000 surgical removal provide the good chance for cure unfortunately the majority of lung cancer case are detect in an advanced stage when surgical resection is impossible this lead to short survival rate and increase mortality rate for lung cancer increase patient suffering and great cost to the healthcare system method that favor early detection are therefore crucial for successful treatment one such method low dose spiral compute tomography ct is being study to determine whether it use a a screening method will lead to early detection and early intervention perhaps impact survival and mortality in lung cancer this method have a modest sensitivity to detect lung cancer but low specificity which lead to many false positive and a low negative predictive value the present study is design to address both of these limitation by 1 identify individual in the population at high risk for develop lung cancer due to smoking habit and decrease pulmonary function for subsequent ct screening and 2 perform biomarker testing in conjunction with the ct scan to improve the ability to discern individual with benign lung nodule from those with malignant tumor the 5th congressional district of kentucky have one of the high rate of lung cancer in the nation and is an ideal location to test the validity sensitivity and specificity feasibility negative and positive predictive value and efficacy stage distribution shift to early stage disease increase survival and decrease cancer specific mortality of these strategy to enhance early detection eligibility criterion inclusion criterion age 55 75 year old identification of a primary care physician can be identify by study staff if need fev1 fvc or 40 pack year current or former within the last 10 year tobacco use that is heavy cigarette smoking history exclusion criterion enrol in any other lung screening or lung cancer prevention trial chest ct within the prior 12 month inability to lie flat with arm raise above the head current or prior personal history of lung cancer prior history of cancer within the last five year or currently receive treatment for cancer except adequately treat non melanomatous skin cancer or in situ cervical cancer life expectancy of le than 5 year patient require supplemental oxygen inability to give informed greeting and blessing to all today i celebrate my 5 year since diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia who celebrate being diagnose with aml or any cancer for that matter but leta s be honest in the cancer lottery aml is not one of the preferred at least if you cling to cancer stat which is something i highly discourage first problem with aml stat specifically the mean dx age of 68ish i have spend substantial time around several aml support group and i routinely meet people in their 50 40 30 and 20 stricken with this demon an amazing christian brother of mine who also is a physician recommend i read an article on cancer stat that i re read often the median is not the messagea i highly recommend it http www cancerguide org mediannotmsg html so back to my celebration first thing you must know about i i am an on fire bible believing sell out save by grace forgive sinner second i absolutely do not believe god give i cancer because nothing bad and i believe all of we know cancer to be very very bad come from a love gracious merciful god such a ours nor is cancer some sort of evil test where god is test i or try to prove my strength for i firmly believe 2 corinthian 12 9 my grace is all you need my power work well in weakness so now i am glad to boast about my weakness so that the power of christ can work through i fight cancer certainly do not show i how strong i am wa the opposite occur for the first time in my adult life i wa completely out of control helpless feckless a powerless a a new bear babe and in that lay bare state for the first time in my life i completely surrender my life my will my future my child over to almighty god and he wa and is faithful i truly leave the peace that pas all understanding like a blanket of comfort on my darkest day that act of surrender and blind faith change my relationship with my lord and savior forever and i will never be the same that is what i celebrate five year ago i wa an otherwise healthy 48 year old mother of three amazing daughter 8 10 and 12 married to the love of my life i work full time for the u air force a a civilian manager and teach mastera s level graduate course part time primarily online i have absolutely no symptom at dx other than a few bruise very typical for i and a very wonky cbc that wa do a part of routine blood work at dx my platelet were 98 wbc wa 1ish and my anc wa 02 and have been there for month i would discover later like most of you i wa refer to a hematologist who base on the cbc and the fact that i have not have any illness to include a cold for year do not think a i have anything to worry abouta but just to be safe go get a bmb to rule anything out 12 hour later i wa admit to the hospital with confirm aml with the dreaded 7 3 red devil chemo drip into my hickman six hour later i wa bless with an amazing medical team at lds hospital in slc ut lead by the amazing finn peterson from denmark who have been specialize in acute leukemia for 30 year he immediately see the shock an awe in my eye and graciously prescribe anti depressant and anti anxiety med that help i so much during my year of chemo dr peterson do an amazing job literally draw on my stainless board in my room cytogenetic component of aml because my very first question wa is aml hereditary with thought of my precious daughter he confirm not hereditary but certainly genetic wait what he ask about exposure to benzene and explain that people around military installation yep 30 year of that and those expose to secondary smoke yep both parent chain smoker have high chance of blood cancer by the way my brother wa dxd with nhl about a year after i so back to my previous comment about cancera s cause yes i believe there is an environmental causation and possibly hereditary for some type but i do think most cancer are random a discus in the johna s hopkin study http hub jhu edu 2017 03 23 cancer mutation cause by random dna mistake and whenever i would start down a pity party about a why mea relative to cancer my mind would always go to child stricken with this disease a adult we can be reason with make to understand why this procedure bmb is necessary but a child good lord how heart wrench that must be my advice to any adult do the why i business go volunteer in a childrena s cancer ward that syndrome will be cure forever he far explain the three category of aml favorable intermediate and unfavorable if i wa in the favorable category i may be able to be treat with chemo only otherwise stem cell transplant wa the treatment path he promise i would know my sub type and any mutation flt3 cebpa ect within two week but job one wa to get i into remission fortunately i tolerate the induction chemo well with only slight mucositis and no other complication not even a fever i manage to walk 3 to 4 mile everyday whether i want to or not a promise 2 week in i wa overjoyed to learn i have inversion 16 with no mutation chemo only for i i spend 28 day in the hospital and send home to return in four week to begin consolidation now this is where my smooth cancer journey go somewhat off the track but i share it in case other have or will experience this anomaly the consolidation process for aml have been the same for decade 30 day between dose six day get chemo hiaric nadir with transfusion for a month and back for another round not this girl although i continue to feel fabulous telework full time for the air force my bone marrow take a huge hit i give myself neopegen shot every day from day 10 to day 40 because my white would not come up and my dang platelet were the scourge the require platelet number to begin another cycle of consolidation wa 100 well mine never get there in fact my consolidation session were twice a long a advertise with a reduce dose from 3 0 to finally 1 5 the european standard by the way we americana s like to hit it with the big gun the great news is by the grace of almighty god who guide my amazing medical team i am in remision and live a very abundant life my med team follow i with quarterly cbc and pcrs for four year and due to over 40 red blood transfusion i require phlebotomy to decrease the iron store on my liver in jan i will be deem cure by my team i am forever grateful i work fulltime take a month long european vacation with my girl and hubby every summer because not to be morbid but tomorrow and your 401k is not guarantee and feel amazing i stay here because through all of this god reveal my purpose to encourage to pray to give hope to those in the fight of their life when i wa dxd i just want to meet talk to someone who survive hope is so critical not all who are dxd with aml have a difficult path we all hear about the hard path i want people to know some have a rather often detect during blood test for a routine physical or other medical procedure if the infection have been present for many year the liver may be permanently scarred a condition call cirrhosis in many case there may be no symptom of the disease until cirrhosis have develop the follow symptom could occur with hepatitis c infection jaundice abdominal pain right upper abdomen fatigue loss of appetite nausea vomit low grade fever pale or clay color stool dark urine generalize itching ascite bleed varix dilate vein in the esophagus hepatitis virus serology elisa assay to detect hepatitis c is the most difficult to treat treatment there is no cure for hepatitis c some patient with hepatitis c benefit from treatment with interferon alpha or a combination of interferon alpha and ribavirin interferon alpha is give by injection just under the skin and have a number of side effect include flu like symptom headache fever fatigue loss of appetite nausea vomiting depression and thinning of hair treatment with interferon alpha may also interfere with the production of white blood cell and platelet ribavirin is a capsule take twice daily and the major side effect is severe anemia low red blood cell ribavirin also cause birth defect woman should therefore avoid pregnancy during and for 6 month follow treatment recently a version of interferon alpha with a long half life pegylate interferon alpha wa introduce and the long half life mean the injection are take weekly instead of the three time a week with standard interferon alpha pegylate interferon alpha and ribavirin lead to a sustained response in approximately 50 of patient a sustained response mean that the patient remain free of hepatitis c virus 6 month after stop therapy approximately 40 of patient with genotype 1 infection will respond rest may be recommend during the acute phase of the disease when the symptom are most severe all patient with hepatitis c should be immunize against hepatitis a and b people with hepatitis c should also be careful not to take vitamin nutritional supplement or new over the counter medication without first discus it with a doctor people with hepatitis c should avoid any substance toxic to the liver hepatotoxic include alcohol even moderate amount of alcohol speed up the progression of hepatitis c and alcohol reduce the effectiveness of treatment the stress of illness can often be ease by join a support group of person who share common experience and problem expectation prognosis hepatitis c is one of the most common cause of chronic liver disease in the you s today at least 80 of patient with acute hepatitis c ultimately develop chronic liver infection and 20 to 30 develop cirrhosis between 1 and 5 of patient may develop liver cancer hepatitis c is now the number 1 cause for liver transplantation in the you s complication chronic hepatitis cirrhosis call your provider if symptom of hepatitis develop or if you believe you have been expose to the of abuse and especially do not share needle with anyone be cautious when get tattoo and body piercing sexual transmission is low among stable monogamous couple a partner should be screen for hepatitis c if the partner is negative the current recommendation are to make no change in sexual practice individual have sex outside of a monogamous relationship should practice safe sex behavior to avoid one of the most important cause of chronic liver disease in the united state it account for about 15 percent of acute viral hepatitis 60 to 70 percent of chronic hepatitis and up to 50 percent of cirrhosis end stage liver disease and liver cancer almost 4 million american or 1 8 percent of the you s population have antibody to hcv anti hcv indicate ongoing or previous infection with the virus hepatitis c cause an estimate 10 000 to 12 000 death annually in the united state a distinct and major characteristic of hepatitis c is it tendency to cause chronic liver disease at least 75 percent of patient with acute hepatitis c ultimately develop chronic infection and most of these patient have accompany chronic liver disease chronic hepatitis c vary greatly in it course and outcome at one end of the spectrum are patient who have no sign or symptom of liver disease and completely normal level of serum liver enzyme liver biopsy usually show some degree of chronic hepatitis but the degree cannabis is a depressant drug depressant drug do not necessarily make you feel depressed rather they slow down the central nervous system and the message go to and from the brain to the body cannabis effect vary from person to person the effect of cannabis are different for each person the effect can vary accord to the mood or atmosphere in which it is use the immediate effect of cannabis can last approximately two to three hour and may include a feeling of relaxation and sense of wellbee reduce concentration decrease coordination distort perception of time space and distance increase heart rate drowsiness increase appetite increase talkativeness reddened eye impair drive ability large dose or strong form of cannabis can exacerbate these effect and result in other effect such a confusion restlessness feeling of excitement hallucination anxiety or panic detachment from reality paranoia nausea long term user may experience additional effect cannabis may also have additional effect on long term user include the risk of asthma emphysema shortness of breath chest infection and throat mouth and lung cancer poor concentration memory loss and learn difficulty depression of the immune system which increase the risk of develop infection serious mental illness such a schizophrenia

if you smoke too much blame your gene say expert smoker who find it hard to cut down or quit may be able to blame their gene new research suggest scientist identify three genetic mutation that increase the number of cigarette people smoke a day and several gene appear to dictate how likely you are to take up smoking and how easily you can quit three separate study collect datum from 140 000 people with the result publish in the journal nature genetic a previous study two year ago find a common single letter change in the genetic code link to nicotine addiction and lung cancer risk this new research confirm this discovery and also pinpoint two more genetic variant that seem to increase cigarette consumption among smoker lung cancer risk the new single letter mutation know a single nucleotide polymorphism or snp lie in region of the dna molecule contain gene believe to influence nicotine addiction in smoker each copy of the variant wa associate with a small increase in smoking consumption equivalent to about half a cigarette a day however they also confer a 10 increase in lung cancer risk raise question about their effect it is not clear whether the variant simply drive people to smoke more or increase susceptibility to cancer a well the university of north carolina oxford university and icelandic company decode were all involve in the research dr kari stefansson researcher and executive chairman of decode stress that smoking is bad for anyone health but it is even bad for some and our discovery continue to strengthen our ability to identify who those people are and give they a compelling reason to quit amanda sandford research manager at ash a public health charity caution that any potential benefit from this research were still a long way in the future smoker who want to quit should not wait for treatment tailor to their genetic make up there is an abundance of advice and treatment available already to help people stop smoke she say http news before hello we are currently look for people to take part in our research study at the university of chester uk on daily function and psychological wellbeing in cancer patient receive a cancer diagnosis and all that come after this can often be a distressing worry and confusing time our before midday is to investigate how cancer have affect your daily functioning and emotional wellbeing we are particularly interested in how this then affect decision you make about your treatment our goal is to help other that might find themselves in your position in the future to do this we need your help anyone who is over 16 year of age and been diagnose with any type of cancer can take part if you decide to take part you will be ask to complete an online questionnaire that will take around 30 minute to complete you will be also ask whether you would like to participate in a phone or skype interview at a later date but you dona t have to agree to this to take part in the questionnaire study while we hope that take part will be a positive experience for you we also understand that answer question about your illness may be upset you can always stop the questionnaire at any time all your answer and datum will be anonymous if you would like to take part please click the following link this will take you to the survey and study information sheet link http chester onlinesurveys ac uk reddit thank you david budzynski before christ hon mre student conduct the research

friend and newcomer i just want to report on my situation that many of you know for those who are new i will detail my case i wa diagnose m5 aml on november 11th 2011 i do not get good result of cytogenetic for some reason old timer lovely dr decide i wa good for just chemo i do induction and three round of consolidation 14 day stint in icu with septic shock survive all and wa in cr until late march of 2013 relapse new cytogenetic and new induction at sloan kettering flt3 and npm1 positive remission after second induction and a week before transplant i relapse again postpone transplant obviously and wa fortunate to go across the street to cornell weil to dr gail roboz absolutely amazing and start plexxicon 3397 clinical trial gain remission again after 6 week from trial drug and have no blast and clean bone marrow biopsy wa put back into transplant at sloan kettering transplant go well and i am now day 62 post transplant i find out today i will be patient zero a a post transplant inhibitor with plexxicon 3397 i begin take it tomorrow prophylactically they will monitor i closely a no one have ever been on it post transplant before unless they relapse i will be take it a a safety net like people today take sorafenib or vidaza i have no idea how this will work but i am truly hope this is the future of flt3 treatment i am hope that flt3 will become the next apl apl use to be the most deadly leukemia and is now 92 curable i feel fortunate to be contribute to the world of medical research and will keep you all post a to how it all go with love for all aml battler ed

hi everyone just want to post an update on jack monday wa pre trial screen for the study ucla is do the second part of this study the first part wa determine dosage the patient are randomize into three group 100 200 300 if those on the 100 do not respond well then the dosage can be increase but those on the high dose can not be decrease there are only 6 patient in the study at ucla and 230 worldwide we are bless and so thankful for this chance pre test involve echocardiogram ekg bmb dilate eye exam visual field and fundus photo my brother wa very worried about getting reject because during his last hospital stay the team discover pericarditis which can happen to long term leukemia patient eye exam demonstrate some mild hemorrhage and anemia in the eye also sign of leukemia all these result are important for baseline the coordinator np have been a saint she wa able to get everything together for a wednesday dosage jack receive a phone call to stop the hydrea that day and he receive his first dose of asp 2215 in the afternoon i have been especially busy at work and do not get to speak with he until late thursday and i wa shock he sound almost normal on the telephone he even joke with i i have not hear he like that this past year he is a very serious guy he say he have more energy but his rear end wa still slightly painful due to the abscess i want to just keep everyone up to date because i know there are several people quite curious about this trial a i wa previously there is very limited info on the result and outcome of patient when i wa look online i am hope this news will be helpful to those who are interested next appointment is monday thank you everyone for the generous support prayer and concern all of you are so awesome and strong

ot for some but not for other new blood test detect cancer early british scientist have devise a test that can spot cancer before a tumour develop write lesley dobson catch cancer early is one of the most important step to treat it successfully now a new blood test have been develop that scientist believe could help to detect cancer up to five year early than is possible with exist test the test know a earlycdt for early cancer detection test is base on the work of professor john robertson he is a renowned breast cancer specialist and professor of surgery at the university of nottinghams faculty of medicine and heath science professor richardson start his research in this area use blood sample from people with breast cancer and from a group of high risk woman who give blood sample with their annual mammogram his test were able to identify the signal for the presence of breast cancer in the blood of a percentage of woman who develop the disease the test were also able to detect the signal in some of the high risk patient before they develop breast cancer new technology develop by oncimmune limit a spin off company from nottingham university have refine the testing process the company believe that this mean early detection of cancer and a change to the way many cancer include lung breast ovarian colon and prostate are diagnose and treat the first test for lung cancer early cdt lung tm is being launch this month in the usa and will be launch in the uk early in 2011 geoffrey hamilton fairley executive chairman of oncimmune say we believe this test along with the other we will launch in the next few year will lead to a well prognosis for a significant number of cancer sufferer a simple effective blood test that can detect cancer before it take hold sound like all our christmas come at once but perhaps we should not get the bauble out just yet nell barrie science information officer at cancer research uk say diagnose cancer early will save life so research into way to detect the disease is vital this approach could be helpful but we need to see the result of large trial before we know for sure how effective these test are at detect cancer in the general population professor stephen spiro deputy chairman of the british lung foundation agree that more work is need before we celebrate the test put people who screen positive into the arena that they may be susceptible to a lung cancer or are develop a lung cancer that is still too small to be see explain professor spiro it a series of test look for a panel of six or seven antibody in the blood each antibody is not a very strong predictor of anything but if people have several of these antibodie the concept is that they may be brew or be susceptible to a lung cancer when they ve look at people know to have lung cancer these auto antibody are find in a high percentage of people there are a lot of people with lung cancer who do not have these antibodie the bottom line will be when they take people who are at high risk of lung cancer say heavy smoker or people who smoke and have copd how many of they will have these auto antibody and if they do have these auto antibody do they eventually turn out to have a lung cancer that study still have to be do having say that it is definitely a step forward because the mean that we have now of detect lung cancer early are pretty hopeless we can not detect it early if you can pick up sign that someone might be susceptible to it in a blood test the challenge then is what to do with those people how carefully should we watch they and how often should they have x ray and thing like that i still think it probable this type of test may well be the way that the field will move to pick up a lung cancer before it become visible on an x ray it go to be a lot of worry if you get a positive blood test any individual will want to know how certain the doctor is that they will or will not develop a tumour and that we do not know stay cancer free is
